questions.text: Which part of the spine is most commonly affected in patients with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
The atlantoaxial joint (C1 & C2) is the most commonly affected part of the spine in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

The joints in rheumatoid arthritis are bilaterally and symmetrically involved. The commonly affected joints are:

  • Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints
  • Wrists
  • Proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints
  • Metatarsophalangeal joints (MTP) joints
  • Atlantoaxial joint

There is relative sparing of the DIP joint in rheumatoid arthritis. The involvement of DIP joints should direct suspicion towards osteoarthritis.

questions.text: Identify the following deformity seen in a patient complaining of pain and swelling of her hands.
questions.solution:
The image is showing flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint is suggestive of Boutonnière deformity seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes are nodules in osteoarthritis that are palpable in the distal interphalangeal joint and proximal interphalangeal joints respectively.

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: A patient presents to your clinic with the following deformity. In which of the following conditions is this deformity seen?
questions.solution:

Boutonnière deformity with flexion at the PIP joint and hyperextension at the DIP joint.

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with a chronic history of pain in the small joints of hands with stiffness of joints in the early hours of the day. The image of the patient’s hands is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows flexion at the PIP joint and extension in the DIP joints which is known as boutonniere deformity which is seen in rheumatoid arthritis(RA). 

If the patient gives a history of pain/stiffness in the joints in the early hours of the day which usually decreases as the day progresses suggesting inflammatory arthritis and if it presents with predominant involvement of smaller joints, it is most likely a case of RA(option A).

It occurs due to the accumulation of inflammatory mediators which on increased joint mobility are flushed out due to increased blood supply. 

Pain and stiffness in osteoarthritis (Option B) usually increase as the day progresses due to an increase in the activity of the joint. They typically present with nodules around the distal interphalangeal joint (Heberden nodes) and proximal interphalangeal joint (Bouchard nodes).

questions.text: What is the most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
The most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis(RA) is subcutaneous nodules.

The nodules are generally benign, non-tender, and firm, and occur in areas subjected to repeated trauma such as the forearm, sacral prominences, and Achilles tendon. They can also occur in the lungs, pleura, pericardium, and peritoneum. 

Patients who have a history of cigarette smoking had early onset arthritic manifestations and tested positive for RA factor or ACPA are more likely to develop extra-articular manifestations. Other common extra-articular manifestations include secondary Sjogren's syndrome, interstitial lung disease, pulmonary nodules, and anemia. FELTY’S syndrome is a triad of neutropenia, splenomegaly, and nodular RA.

questions.text: Which of the following would you not expect to see in a patient diagnosed with Felty syndrome?
questions.solution:
Hepatomegaly is not seen in Felty syndrome. 

Felty syndrome is defined by the clinical triad of:

  • Neutropenia
  • Splenomegaly
  • Rheumatoid arthritis

It occurs in the late stages of rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

Other syndromes associated with rheumatoid arthritis are:

  • Caplan’s syndrome- characterized by both rheumatoid arthritis and pneumoconiosis. It is associated with development of multiple peripheral basilar nodules in the lungs. 
  • Secondary Sjogren’s syndrome- development of keratoconjunctivitis sicca or xerostomia in association with connective tissue disorder.

questions.text: Which is the most common type of lymphoma seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
The most common histopathologic type of lymphoma seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis is diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL).

The risk of developing lymphoma increases if the patient has Felty’s syndrome or high levels of disease activity.

questions.text: A patient complains about difficulty doing chores due to morning stiffness of the joints. Investigations show elevated ESR, CRP, and positive Rheumatoid factor. Which of the following is not likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis, which is associated with hypoandrogenism. 

It is characterized by low levels of serum testosterone, LH, and DHEA.

The conditions associated with rheumatoid arthritis are:

  • Cardiovascular disease, congestive heart failure
  • Osteoporosis - hip fractures are more likely to occur
  • Ocular - keratoconjunctivitis sicca, episcleritis, scleritis, keratitis
  • Secondary Sjogren's syndrome
  • Hypoandrogenism in men and postmenopausal women

questions.text: All of the following characteristics are found in the pleural effusion fluid of a rheumatoid arthritis patient except:
questions.solution:
Low glucose (<60 mg/dL) is seen in the pleural effusion fluid of a patient with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

RA causes exudative pleural effusion and fulfills the Light’s criteria. High LDH and RA factor are found in the pleural fluid of RA patients. Less commonly, patients with RA may have a cholesterol effusion. It is sterile and has a milky or opaque appearance. The milky appearance is due to the presence of cholesterol crystals and an elevated cholesterol level.

Light’s criteria is used to distinguish between exudative and transudative pleural effusions. An exudative pleural effusion satisfies at least one of the following criteria:

  • Pleural fluid protein/serum protein > 0.5
  • Pleural fluid LDH / serum LDH > 0.6
  • Pleural fluid LDH more than 2/3rds upper limit of normal for serum

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure (most common)
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome

  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Urinothorax
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Infections: Tuberculosis, pneumonia, intraabdominal abscess (like- liver abscess)
  • Malignancy: Pleural mesothelioma, metastasis, lymphoma
  • Connective tissue diseases: SLE, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Drugs: Amiodarone, bromocriptine, dantrolene, dasatinib, methysergide, nitrofurantoin

    • Hemothorax

    • Yellow nail syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following radiological features would help to differentiate between rheumatoid arthritis and SLE?
questions.solution:
Articular erosions on X-ray is seen in rheumatoid arthritis (RA), but not in SLE.

Juxta-articular osteoporosis, swelling of PIP joint, and ulnar deviation can be seen in both SLE and RA.

Jaccoud arthropathy is a deforming non-erosive arthropathy characterized by the ulnar deviation of the second to 5th fingers with metacarpophalangeal joint subluxation seen in SLE.

questions.text: In a suspected case of rheumatoid arthritis, which of the following markers should be used to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate marker to diagnose rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is the anti-CCP (cyclic citrullinated peptide) antibody as it is the most specific marker for RA.

Anti-CCP, ESR, and CRP values correlate with the disease activity.

Rheumatoid factor can occur in other autoimmune diseases as well as in chronic infections. Therefore it is not considered specific.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for the treatment of a patient with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Methotrexate which is a DMARD is the drug of choice for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

A combination regimen is used when there is a failure to achieve adequate improvement with methotrexate only. 

Methotrexate in low doses causes adenosine release and suppresses joint inflammation. However, in high doses, it causes inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR).

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis is being treated with methotrexate and low-dose corticosteroids for the past 4 months. However, the disease is still progressing. What would be your recommendation for the further management of this patient?

choices.text: Stop oral methotrexate and start parenteral methotrexate

questions.solution:
For further management of a patient with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) with worsening disease activity, the preferred therapy is a step-up to oral triple therapy with methotrexate, sulfasalazine, and hydroxychloroquine. The addition of leflunomide or a biological (anti - TNF) to methotrexate is another alternative.

Ideally, the approach to a patient with early RA is aggressive. Methotrexate is always the first DMARD that the patient is started on, and if an adequate response is not observed within 3-6 months, a step up in therapy is made by adding on drugs.

For assessment of progression, composite indices like Disease Activity Score - 28 (DAS-28) can used.

Other options:

Option A: Changing the route of administration of methotrexate from oral to parenteral is not a part of step up 

Option C: Priority is given to minimising the duration the patient is on steroids.

Option D: Anti -TNF agents (adalimumab, etanercept) are not recommended as a monotherapy, and are reserved for treatment in combination with DMARDs. This is due to the fact that the efficacy of monotherapy is lesser than that of DMARDs, and the adverse effects include increased risk of serious infections, re-activation of latent TB and opportunistic fungal infections. They are reserved for cases where there is a lack of response with the first line agents.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Janus kinase inhibitor used in patients with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
The Janus kinase inhibitor used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis is tofacitinib.

Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are Janus kinase inhibitors used as monotherapy or combination therapy in rheumatoid arthritis.

Option A: Anakinra is an IL-1 antagonist.

Option B: Tocilizumab is an IL-6 antagonist.

Option C: Abatacept acts by inhibiting co-stimulation of T cells.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant lady visits your OPD with complaints of painful swelling of her hands since past 2 months. Investigations reveal positive rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP antibodies. Which of the following DMARDs should not be prescribed to her?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Leflunomide should not be prescribed in pregnancy as it is a category X drug.

DMARDs classified as Category X in pregnancy (contraindicated in pregnancy) are:

  • Methotrexate 
  • Leflunomide

questions.text: What is the isotype of the rheumatoid factor most commonly measured in the laboratory?
questions.solution:
IgM isotype is the rheumatoid factor (RF) most commonly measured in laboratories.

IgM RF has been found in 75–80% of patients with rheumatoid arthritis. IgG and IgA isotypes of RF have also been identified.

However, RF is not specific for rheumatoid arthritis and can also be found in the following conditions:

  • Primary Sjögren’s syndrome
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Subacute bacterial endocarditis
  • Hepatitis B and C

questions.text: Iritis is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Iritis is seen in all the above conditions except rheumatoid arthritis.

Iritis or iridocyclitis is also known as anterior uveitis. 

Anterior uveitis is seen in:

  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis
  • Psoriasis
  • Reactive arthritis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Leprosy

Posterior uveitis is seen in:

  • Vogt-Koyanagi Harada syndrome
  • Diseases like toxoplasmosis, cysticercosis, coccidioidomycosis, toxocariasis, histoplasmosis
  • Infections- Candida, Pneumocystis carinii, Cryptococcus, Aspergillus, and Cytomegalovirus
  • Cat-scratch disease, Whipple’s disease, and brucellosis

Both anterior and posterior uveitis is seen in:

  • Sarcoidosis
  • Behcet's disease
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Herpes infections, Syphilis, Lyme disease, TB, onchocerciasis

Intermediate uveitis/pars planitis is seen in multiple sclerosis.
